General Syntax

On this page

Lexical Structure ‚Äã

Version: 0.1.0
Last Updated: November 3, 2025

This document defines the lexical structure of the Vex programming language, including tokens, identifiers, literals, operators, and comments.

Table of Contents ‚Äã

  1. Source Code Encoding
  2. Comments
  3. Whitespace and Line Terminators
  4. Identifiers
  5. Keywords
  6. Operators and Punctuation
  7. Literals
  8. Token Types

Source Code Encoding ‚Äã

Vex source files:

  • File Extension: .vx
  • Encoding: UTF-8
  • Line Endings: LF (\n) or CRLF (\r\n)
  • BOM: Not required, but accepted if present

Comments ‚Äã

Vex supports two types of comments that are ignored by the lexer:

Line Comments ‚Äã

Begin with // and continue until the end of the line.

rust
// This is a line comment
let x = 42; // Inline comment after code

Block Comments ‚Äã

Begin with /* and end with */. Can span multiple lines.

rust
/*
 * This is a multi-line
 * block comment
 */

/* Inline block comment */ let y = 100;

Note: Block comments do not nest in the current implementation.

Whitespace and Line Terminators ‚Äã

The following characters are considered whitespace and are skipped by the lexer:

  • Space (U+0020)
  • Tab (U+0009)
  • Line Feed (U+000A)
  • Form Feed (U+000C)

Regex Pattern: [ \t\n\f]+

Semicolons ‚Äã

Semicolons (;) are optional in Vex. A newline character generally terminates a statement. Semicolons are only required when placing multiple statements on the same line.

rust
// Valid
let x = 10
let y = 20

// Also valid (multiple statements on one line)
let a = 1; let b = 2

Whitespace is used to separate tokens but is otherwise ignored.

Identifiers ‚Äã

Identifiers are names for variables, functions, types, and other program entities.

Syntax Rules ‚Äã

  • First Character: Must be a letter (a-z, A-Z) or underscore (_)
  • Subsequent Characters: Letters, digits (0-9), or underscores
  • Case Sensitive: myVar, MyVar, and myvar are different identifiers

Regex Pattern: [a-zA-Z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*

Valid Identifiers ‚Äã

rust
variable
_private
count_123
camelCase
snake_case
PascalCase
__double_underscore

Invalid Identifiers ‚Äã

rust
123start     // Cannot start with digit
my-var       // Hyphen not allowed
my.var       // Dot not allowed
fn           // Reserved keyword

Naming Conventions ‚Äã

While not enforced by the compiler, the following conventions are recommended:

EntityConventionExample
Variablessnake_caseuser_count
ConstantsUPPER_SNAKE_CASEMAX_SIZE
Functionssnake_casecalculate_total
Types (Structs, Enums)PascalCaseUserAccount
ContractsPascalCaseSerializable
Internal/HelperPrefix with __internal_fn

Keywords ‚Äã

Keywords are reserved identifiers with special meaning in the language.

Control Flow Keywords ‚Äã

if          else        elif        for
while       in          match       switch
case        default     return      break
continue    defer

Answer: ‚úÖ for keyword mevcut ve √ßalƒ±≈üƒ±yor. 06_Control_Flow.md'de detaylƒ± dok√ºmante edilmi≈ü. Answer: ‚úÖ defer keyword IMPLEMENTED! (Nov 9, 2025) - Go-style resource cleanup with LIFO execution.

Declaration Keywords ‚Äã

fn          let         const       struct
enum        type        contract    impl
extern      policy      with        loop
where       typeof      any

Special Syntax: fn! (fn followed by !) declares an unsafe function. See 05_Functions_and_Methods.md.

Note: ‚ùå static keyword not added. Use const instead. Global mutable variables may be considered in the future.

Type Keywords ‚Äã

i8          i16         i32         i64
i128        u8          u16         u32
u64         u128        f16         f32
f64         bool        string      byte
error       nil         any

Answer:

  • ‚ùå void - Zaten nil kullanƒ±yoruz (unit type)
  • ‚úÖ i128/u128 - Destekleniyor (crypto/big numbers i√ßin).
  • ‚ùå i256/u256 - Gerek yok, √ßok spesifik use case (blockchain)
  • ‚úÖ f16 - Destekleniyor. f8/f128 ≈üu an √∂ncelik deƒüil.

Module Keywords ‚Äã

import      export      from        as

Concurrency Keywords ‚Äã

async       await       go          select

Advanced Keywords ‚Äã

unsafe      new         make        try
extends     infer       contract

Boolean Literals ‚Äã

true        false

Total Reserved Keywords: 64

Deprecated Keywords ‚Äã

  • mut - Removed in v0.1 (use let! for mutable variables)
  • interface - Use contract instead
  • gpu - Deprecated in v0.2 (compiler auto-detects GPU opportunities)
  • launch - Deprecated in v0.2 (automatic dispatch replaces manual launch)
  • @vectorize - Deprecated in v0.2 (compiler auto-vectorizes)
  • @gpu - Deprecated in v0.2 (automatic GPU detection)

Note: See 25_Automatic_Optimization.md for the new automatic hardware optimization model.

Operators and Punctuation ‚Äã

Arithmetic Operators ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescriptionExample
Addition+Add two valuesa + b
Subtraction-Subtract valuesa - b
Multiplication*Multiply valuesa * b
Division/Divide valuesa / b
Modulo%Remaindera % b

Comparison Operators ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescription
Equal==Equality test
Not Equal!=Inequality test
Less Than<Less than
Less or Equal<=Less than or equal
Greater Than>Greater than
Greater or Equal>=Greater than or equal

Logical Operators ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescription
Logical AND&&Both conditions true
Logical OR||At least one condition true
Logical NOT!Negate condition

Bitwise Operators (Future) ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescription
Bitwise AND&Bitwise AND
Bitwise OR|Bitwise OR
Bitwise XOR^Bitwise XOR
Left Shift<<Shift left
Right Shift>>Shift right

Assignment Operators ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescription
Assign=Assignment
Add Assign+=Add and assign
Subtract Assign-=Subtract and assign
Multiply Assign*=Multiply and assign
Divide Assign/=Divide and assign
Modulo Assign%=Modulo and assign
Bitwise AND&=AND and assign
Bitwise OR|=OR and assign
Bitwise XOR^=XOR and assign
Left Shift<<=Shift left assign
Right Shift>>=Shift right assign

Answer: ‚úÖ Bitwise assignment operators eklenmeli (Medium Priority üü°). Bitwise operat√∂rler zaten planned olduƒüu i√ßin bunlar da eklenecek.

Answer: ‚úÖ Increment/Decrement (++/--) operat√∂rleri destekleniyor (Postfix only: x++, x--).

Reference Operators ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescriptionExample
Reference&Take reference&x
Dereference*Dereference pointer*ptr
Mutable Ref!Mutable marker&x!

Answer: Stack i√ßin & reference, heap allocation i√ßin new keyword kullanƒ±lacak (future). Raw pointer i√ßin unsafe blok i√ßinde manual allocation gerekecek.

Answer: ‚úÖ ++/-- operat√∂rleri destekleniyor.

Other Operators ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescription
Member Access.Access field or method
Range..Exclusive range operator
Range Inclusive..=Inclusive range operator
Variadic...Variadic arguments
Try?Error propagation
Pipe|OR pattern in match

Null Safety Operators ‚úÖ NEW ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescriptionExample
Null Coalesce??Default value if nilx ?? 0
Optional Chaining?.Safe member accessuser?.name
Error Rescue!>Handle error with fallbackresult !> |e| default

Null Coalesce (??): Returns left operand if not nil, otherwise returns right operand.

rust
let name = user.nickname ?? user.username ?? "Anonymous";
let count = map.get("key") ?? 0;

Optional Chaining (?.): Safely access members, returns nil if receiver is nil.

rust
let city = user?.address?.city;  // nil if user or address is nil
let len = str?.len();            // nil if str is nil

Error Rescue (!>): Handle Result errors inline with closure or function.

rust
let data = parse_json(text) !> |e| default_data;
let value = risky_op() !> handle_error;

See Error_rescue_operator.spec.md for full specification.

Power and Bitwise Operators ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescriptionExample
Power**Exponentiation2 ** 10
Bitwise NOT~Bitwise complement~x

Power (**): Raises left operand to the power of right operand.

rust
let square = x ** 2;
let cube = x ** 3;
let result = 2 ** 10;  // 1024

Bitwise NOT (~): Inverts all bits.

rust
let mask = ~0xFF;  // Invert bits

Increment/Decrement Operators ‚úÖ ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescriptionExample
Post-Inc++Increment afterx++
Post-Dec--Decrement afterx--
Pre-Inc++Increment before++x
Pre-Dec--Decrement before--x
rust
let! x = 5;
x++;       // x is now 6
let y = x++;  // y = 6, x = 7
let z = ++x;  // z = 8, x = 8

Channel Operators (Concurrency) ‚Äã

OperatorSymbolDescriptionExample
Channel Receive<-Receive from ch<-channel
Channel SendmethodSend to channelch.send(x)

Channel Receive (<-): Receives a value from a channel (Go-style).

rust
let ch = Channel.new<i32>();
go { ch.send(42); };
let value = <-ch;  // Receives 42

See 13_Concurrency.md for full channel documentation.

Note: üü° Spread/Rest operators (...arr) planned for future.

Delimiters ‚Äã

SymbolNameUsage
( )ParenthesesFunction calls, grouping, tuples
{ }BracesBlocks, struct literals
[ ]BracketsArrays, indexing
,CommaSeparate items
;SemicolonStatement terminator
:ColonType annotations
_UnderscoreWildcard pattern

Special Symbols ‚Äã

SymbolNameUsage
=>Fat ArrowMatch arms, lambdas
@AtIntrinsics (reserved, minimal)

Note: Vex does NOT use Rust-style #[attribute] syntax. The @ symbol is reserved for future compiler intrinsics but @vectorize and @gpu are deprecated in favor of automatic optimization (see 25_Automatic_Optimization.md).

Literals ‚Äã

Integer Literals ‚Äã

Decimal integers without any prefix:

rust
0           // Zero
42          // Positive integer
-100        // Negative integer (unary minus + literal)

Type: i64 by default (can be inferred or explicitly typed)

Regex Pattern: [0-9]+

Supported Formats:

  • Hexadecimal: 0xFF, 0x1A2B
  • Octal: 0o77, 0o644
  • Binary: 0b1010, 0b11110000
  • Underscores: 1_000_000, 0xFF_FF_FF

Floating-Point Literals ‚Äã

Decimal numbers with a decimal point:

rust
0.0
3.14
2.71828
-0.5        // Negative (unary minus + literal)

Type: f64 by default

Regex Pattern: [0-9]+\.[0-9]+

Future Extensions:

  • Scientific notation: 1.5e10, 2.0E-5
  • Type suffix: 3.14f32, 2.0f64

Boolean Literals ‚Äã

rust
true        // Boolean true
false       // Boolean false

Type: bool

String Literals ‚Äã

Enclosed in double quotes with escape sequences:

rust
"Hello, World!"
"Line 1\nLine 2"
"Tab\tseparated"
"Quote: \"Hello\""
"Backslash: \\"

Type: string

Regex Pattern: "([^"\\]|\\["\\bnfrt]|u[a-fA-F0-9]{4})*"

Supported Escape Sequences:

SequenceMeaning
\"Double quote
\\Backslash
\nNewline (LF)
\rCarriage return
\tTab
\bBackspace
\fForm feed
\uXXXXUnicode code point (4 hex digits)

F-String Literals (Interpolation) ‚Äã

Strings with embedded expressions, prefixed with f:

rust
let name = "Alice";
let age = 30;
let greeting = f"Hello, {name}! You are {age} years old.";

Type: string

Regex Pattern: f"([^"\\]|\\["\\bnfrt]|u[a-fA-F0-9]{4})*"

Note: Current implementation parses f-strings but full interpolation support is in progress.

Nil Literal ‚Äã

rust
nil         // Represents absence of value

Type: Unit type (void)

Struct Tags (Go-Style) ‚Äã

Metadata attached to struct fields, enclosed in backticks:

rust
struct User {
    id: i64       `json:"id" db:"primary_key"`,
    name: string  `json:"name" validate:"required"`,
}

Type: Metadata (compile-time only)

Regex Pattern: `[^`]*`

Token Types ‚Äã

Token Categories ‚Äã

The lexer produces tokens in the following categories:

1. Keywords (67 tokens) ‚Äã

  • Control flow: if, else, elif, for, while, match, switch, etc.
  • Declarations: fn, let, const, struct, enum, contract, impl
  • Types: i8, i16, i32, i64, u8, u16, u32, u64, f32, f64, bool, string
  • Concurrency: async, await, go, gpu
  • Other: import, export, return, nil, true, false

2. Operators (37 tokens) ‚Äã

  • Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, %
  • Comparison: ==, !=, <, <=, >, >=
  • Logical: &&, ||, !
  • Assignment: =, +=, -=, *=, /=, %=
  • Reference: &, *
  • Other: ., .., ?, |

3. Delimiters (15 tokens) ‚Äã

  • Parentheses: (, )
  • Braces: {, }
  • Brackets: [, ]
  • Separators: ,, ;, :
  • Special: ->, =>, _, #, ...

4. Literals (5 token types) ‚Äã

  • IntLiteral(i64) - Integer values
  • FloatLiteral(f64) - Floating-point values
  • StringLiteral(String) - Regular strings
  • FStringLiteral(String) - Interpolated strings
  • Tag(String) - Struct field tags

5. Identifiers (1 token type) ‚Äã

  • Ident(String) - User-defined names

6. Intrinsics (2 tokens) ‚Äã

  • @vectorize - SIMD vectorization hint
  • @gpu - GPU kernel marker

Total Token Types: ~127

Token Representation ‚Äã

Internally, tokens are represented as:

rust
pub struct TokenSpan {
    pub token: Token,
    pub span: std::ops::Range<usize>,
}

Where:

  • token: The token type and associated value
  • span: Source position (start..end byte offsets)

Lexing Process ‚Äã

Tokenization Steps ‚Äã

  1. Whitespace Skipping: Spaces, tabs, newlines, and form feeds are skipped
  2. Comment Removal: Line and block comments are ignored
  3. Token Matching: Longest match wins using Logos lexer
  4. Error Handling: Invalid characters produce LexError::InvalidToken

Ambiguity Resolution ‚Äã

When multiple patterns match, the lexer uses the following rules:

  1. Longest Match: Prefer longer token (e.g., == over =)
  2. Keyword Priority: Keywords take precedence over identifiers
  3. Operator Priority: Compound operators over simple ones (e.g., <= over <)

Examples:

  • let ‚Üí Keyword Let, not identifier
  • <= ‚Üí Single token LtEq, not Lt + Eq
  • f"string" ‚Üí FStringLiteral, not Ident + StringLiteral

Error Handling ‚Äã

Invalid tokens produce a LexError:

rust
pub enum LexError {
    InvalidToken { span: std::ops::Range<usize> }
}

Example Error:

rust
let x = @;  // '@' alone is invalid (only @vectorize, @gpu are valid)

Implementation Notes ‚Äã

Lexer Technology ‚Äã

Vex uses the Logos lexer generator for efficient tokenization:

  • Declarative: Token definitions via Rust attributes
  • Zero-Copy: Slices source without allocation where possible
  • Fast: Compiled to optimized DFA
  • Error Recovery: Continues after invalid tokens

Performance Characteristics ‚Äã

  • Time Complexity: O(n) where n is source length
  • Space Complexity: O(1) (streaming, no full token buffer)
  • Throughput: ~500 MB/s on modern hardware

Examples ‚Äã

Complete Lexing Example ‚Äã

Input:

rust
fn add(a: i32, b: i32): i32 {
    return a + b;
}

Tokens:

Fn
Ident("add")
LParen
Ident("a")
Colon
I32
Comma
Ident("b")
Colon
I32
RParen
Colon
I32
LBrace
Return
Ident("a")
Plus
Ident("b")
Semicolon
RBrace

String Literals ‚Äã

Input:

rust
"Hello, \"World\"!\n"
f"User: {name}, Age: {age}"
`json:"user_id"`

Tokens:

StringLiteral("Hello, \"World\"!\n")
FStringLiteral("User: {name}, Age: {age}")
Tag("json:\"user_id\"")
